text: On this #NationalHousingDay, we refuse to accept the City‚Äôs deliberate neglect of our meager social housing supply and we‚Äôre prepared to escalate the fight to restore the dignity that is stolen from us every day. https://t.co/w8a2uiHxbR
("Jason" is using a pseudonym here out of fear of retribution)

You wouldn‚Äôt want to live with constant infestations, gas leaks, guest limits, restricted access to other floors, threats from management, faulty plumbing, asbestos exposure, black mold, fire hazards, and broken elevators ‚Äî so why should anyone?

It‚Äôs no secret that Toronto‚Äôs shelters are so squalid & deadly that many take their chances freezing in a tent.

But did you know that the City‚Äôs ‚Äúpermanent housing solutions‚Äù are often so bad, even after fighting to get housing for years, many are forced back to the street?

Building power doesn‚Äôt start at the ballot box every 4 years. It starts in our communities every day, in the bonds btw neighbours, co-workers & comrades.

We can only look to each other to improve our material conditions by modelling the revolutionary relations of a just future.
These are but a few examples of the ruling class‚Äôs ongoing consolidation against the working class who built this city and keep it running ‚Äî who create the value which, in turn, forces us out.

In addition, council recently appointed former cop & architect of last summer‚Äôs encampment evictions Tracey Cook as City Manager. Yday‚Äôs election also saw John ‚ÄúChair Boy‚Äù Burnside elected to council: another former cop who months ago stole property from encampment residents. https://t.co/ot7na1Bccf

All of this legislated immiseration has been violently enforced by the police, receiving exorbitant amounts of funds on Tory‚Äôs watch. Worse, Toronto is embarking on a new order of private security firms patrolling what has become a battlefield for those simply fighting to exist. https://t.co/FkpENVFpux

Yet, landlords who push people out of the city vote to continue this predation. Land-owning Ontarians can vote in each municipality where they own property, even if they don‚Äôt live there. When we say that property rights are enshrined in law as sacrosanct, we‚Äôre not exaggerating https://t.co/tk2GtTt7hN

Tory has repeatedly refused to implement an eviction moratorium ‚Äî even as the pandemic and its resulting precarity continues to price a massive wave of renters out. These former Torontonians do not have the option of voting themselves back into the city. https://t.co/xXx84fWogf

To manufacture consent for such policies, the City of Toronto has engaged in a relentless propaganda campaign to paint the people it deprives of housing as dangerous criminals who threaten the safety of the city‚Äôs housed residents ‚Äî going so far as weaponizing the fire department https://t.co/TQHn0dtNQY

The unhoused individuals who lost their lives during Tory‚Äôs tenure had friends, partners, parents and kids, none of whom have the option of voting their loved ones back into their lives. https://t.co/2lQ8GLxSpE

Encampment evictions, pushing people into ‚Äòtransitional‚Äô shelters, inadequate & carceral drug rehab/mental health facilities, hostile architecture, under-resourced public spaces and unaffordable rents all fed into the City‚Äôs ultimate goal: leaving people to die out of sight. https://t.co/aV3XwNmetb

Over Tory‚Äôs last two terms, *at least* 500+ unhoused community members died as a direct result of his anti-poor policies. At the mayoral debate last week, community members erected a tent bearing the many names of unhoused individuals who lost their lives during Tory‚Äôs tenure. https://t.co/9zNTGp5KsK

Encampments are often the best option in a failed system.

Fundraised supplies will be shared with other orgs working with unhoused people across the city to resist John Tory's callous displacement tactics in the fight for housing and autonomy.

‚öîÔ∏èüî•

People set up tents in parks as a matter of survival, not preference. 

Some have left the shelter system after repeated harassment or violence, others are fleeing abuse. There are elderly people with mobility issues who can‚Äôt access basic support.

After putting out a call for a private security firm to patrol our parks with the power to make discretionary arrests, the City announced that they're closing shelter hotels. 

This is a clear attempt to force unhoused people out of sight, cut off from their lifesaving supports.
